text: The 2019 OFC Champions League Final was the final match of the 2019 OFC Champions League, the 18th edition of the Oceanian Club Championship, Oceania's premier club football tournament organized by the Oceania Football Confederation (OFC), and the 13th season under the current OFC Champions League name. The final was contested as a single match between New Caledonian teams Magenta and Hienghène Sport. The match took place at the Stade Numa-Daly Magenta in Nouméa on 11 May 2019. Hienghène Sport won the final 1–0 for their first OFC Champions League title. ==Teams== In the following table, finals until 2006 were in the Oceania Club Championship era, since 2007 were in the OFC Champions League era. {| class="wikitable" |- !Team !Previous finals appearances (bold indicates winners) |- | Magenta |1 (2005) |- | Hienghène Sport |None |} The final was the first all-New Caledonian final, and guaranteed that for the first time that the OFC club champions were from New Caledonia. This was also the first final since 2005 not to feature a team from New Zealand, and the first ever not to feature any team from New Zealand or Australia (which left the OFC after 2005). ==Venue== The Stade Numa-Daly Magenta was the venue for the final. This was the first time that the stadium hosted an OFC Champions League final. ==Road to the final== Note: In all results below, the score of the finalist is given first (H: home; A: away; N: neutral). {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center" |- !colspan="2"| Magenta !Round !colspan="2"| Hienghène Sport |- style="background:#C1E0FF" |Opponent |Result |Group stage |Opponent |Result |- |style="text-align:left"| Auckland City |1–2 (N) |style="background:#C1E0FF"|Matchday 1 |style="text- align:left"| Malampa Revivors |5–0 (H) |- |style="text-align:left"| Solomon Warriors |3–0 (A) |style="background:#C1E0FF"|Matchday 2 |style="text- align:left"| Tefana |1–0 (H) |- |style="text-align:left"| Tupapa Maraerenga |10–1 (N) |style="background:#C1E0FF"|Matchday 3 |style="text-align:left"| Toti City |1–1 (H) |- |colspan="2" style="vertical-align:top"|Group D runners- up |style="background:#C1E0FF"|Final standings |colspan="2" style="vertical- align:top"|Group A winners |- style="background:#C1E0FF" |Opponent |Result |Knockout stage |Opponent |Result |- |style="text-align:left"| Central Sport |8–0 (A) |style="background:#C1E0FF"|Quarter-finals |style="text-align:left"| Ba |2–1 (H) |- |style="text-align:left"| Auckland City |2–1 (H) |style="background:#C1E0FF"|Semi-finals |style="text-align:left"| Team Wellington |2–0 (H) |} ==Format== In the final, the two semi-final winners played each other, with the host team decided by draw, which was held on 5 March 2019 at the OFC Headquarters in Auckland, New Zealand. Based on the draw, Magenta (winner of semi-final 2) were the home team. If the match was level at the end of 90 minutes of normal playing time, extra time would be played (two periods of 15 minutes each), where each team would be allowed to make a fourth substitution. If still tied after extra time, the match would be decided by a penalty shoot-out to determine the winners. ==Match== ===Details=== {| width=92% |- | | |} {| width="100%" |valign="top" width="40%"| {| style="font-size:90%" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" |- !width=25| !!width=25| |- |GK ||1 || Steve Ixoée |- |RB ||7 || Kevin Maitran |- |CB ||4 || Gaétan Gope-Iwate || |- |CB ||5 || Mickael Tiaou || |- |LB ||3 || Jean-Brice Wadriako (c) |- |CM ||21|| Wilsen Poameno || || |- |CM ||15|| Didier Simane |- |AM ||10|| Richard Sele |- |RF ||2 || Jean-Christ Wajoka |- |CF ||8 || Nathanaël Hmaen |- |LF ||11|| Kevin Nemia || |- |colspan=3|Substitutes: |- |GK ||16|| Nicodem Hmaen |- |DF ||13|| Jean-Marie Hmaloko |- |DF ||14|| Jean-Claude Jewine |- |MF ||12|| Shene Wélépane |- |MF ||17|| Yorick Hnautra |- |FW ||9 || Emile Ounei |- |FW ||18|| Leon Wahnawe || || |- |colspan=3|Manager: |- |colspan=3| Alain Moizan |} |valign="top"|300px |valign="top" width="50%"| {| style="font-size:90%; margin:auto" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" |- !width=25| !!width=25| |- |GK ||1 || Rocky Nyikeine |- |RB ||3 || William Yentao || || |- |CB ||13|| Roy Kayara |- |CB ||5 || Jordan Dinet || |- |LB ||26|| Erwan Ausu |- |CM ||20|| Cédric Sansot |- |CM ||8 || Geordy Gony |- |AM ||10|| Miguel Kayara || || |- |RW ||7 || Anthony Kaï || || |- |CF ||11|| Bertrand Kaï (c) |- |LW ||9 || Brice Dahité |- |colspan=3|Substitutes: |- |GK ||19|| Jacques Nyikeine |- |DF ||2 || Joris Gorendiawé |- |DF ||4 || Bruno Hyanem || || |- |FW ||12|| Antoine Roine || || |- |FW ||23|| Nelson Kaï |- |FW ||28|| Franck Sinem |- |FW ||30|| Yvanoe Bamy || || |- |colspan=3|Manager: |- |colspan=3| Félix Tagawa |} |} {| style="width:100%; font-size:90%;" | Assistant referees: Tevita Makasini (Tonga) Mark Ruke (New Zealand) Fourth official: Campbell-Kirk Waugh (New Zealand) |style="width:60%; vertical-align:top;"| Match rules *90 minutes. *30 minutes of extra time if scores level. *Penalty shoot-out if scores still level. *Maximum of three substitutions, with a fourth allowed in extra time. |} ==References== ==External links== * 2019 Final Category:May 2019 sports events in Oceania Category:AS Magenta Category:Hienghène Sport Category:2019 in New Caledonian football Category:Sport in Nouméa Category:21st century in Nouméa Category:International association football competitions hosted by New Caledonia
title: 2019 OFC Champions League Final
